title: Anthony Borges who used his body to hold his class door shut from a gunman, protecting his 20 classmates whilst being shot through the door five times. Fortunately he survived and has made a complete recovery.
author: Valloreiaiv

high_score_comments.author: GrimdarkGarage
high_score_comments.body: Someone throw money at this kid so he never has to work. Dude has paid enough tax to warrant a comfortable life

high_score_comments.author: [deleted]
high_score_comments.body: If you get shot five times in the torso, there's a good chance they you'll have life altering injuries that would impede his ability to do so. Plus the PTSD and other mental health issues arising from trauma.

high_score_comments.author: just-another-meatbag
high_score_comments.body: Yes, however these stories are often embellished with "complete recovery", he will likely have chunks and pieces missing from some pretty important organs that will forever effect him, if there has been any damage to his spine then that'll restrict him drastically.

high_score_comments.author: [deleted]
high_score_comments.body: Yeah I ended up looking it up, and the most recent information I could find indicates that he does have some severe life altering injuries that remain and that he may not recover from. You can see my most recent comment for that info.

high_score_comments.author: LampshadesAndCutlery
high_score_comments.body:
I think by complete recovery, people usually mean “didn’t die and can still kinda function as everyone else” 

Complete recovery sounds better even if misleading

high_score_comments.author: just-another-meatbag
high_score_comments.body: Yeah that's recovery, not complete recovery, I know it's semantics.

high_score_comments.author: TheHemogoblin
high_score_comments.body: Nah, that's not even semantics, that's an entirely different thing I'd say.

high_score_comments.author: Zirdex1
high_score_comments.body: I agree with the psychology part, but doesn't complete recovery mean that there are no long lasting health problems?

high_score_comments.author: Jgood1414
high_score_comments.body:
Personally, I understand it to be “you are 100% recovered” as in your body has done all it can. 
Mental aspects aside, I have had multiple surgeries due to my little vacation across the pond. I am cleared 100% recovered physically, however I am disabled due to it. Although my body has completed 100% of its healing and “recovered” , my new normal is not 100% of what it was before.

high_score_comments.author: Zirdex1
high_score_comments.body: ah okay, thanks for explaining it

high_score_comments.author: petethered
high_score_comments.body:
> little vacation across the pond

I admit I googled this and still not sure what this is in reference to.

What happened?

high_score_comments.author: sinisterpurple
high_score_comments.body: I'm guessing veteran that was injured while deployed over seas.

high_score_comments.author: petethered
high_score_comments.body: Ahh... that makes sense.  Thanks.

high_score_comments.author: dennismfrancisart
high_score_comments.body: Almost got kneecapped by a .22 shot from a rifle back in the 80s. The scar is there and although it doesn't hurt, thinking about what happened still stresses me out at times. This kid is going to take some time to really recover.

high_score_comments.author: cassiusxwithanxiety
high_score_comments.body:
He once said, and I quote his father: *"People can't call me a hero. A hero doesn't get hurt. You can't call me a hero if I just got 5 bullets and will no longer play football."*

Such a humble soul. At least he survived and had a strong recovery. He even got to go to Barcelona and watch one of the club's games in their stadium. 

His definition of being a hero might not comply to his standards, but to many of us that's what he is.

high_score_comments.author: juttep1
high_score_comments.body: Fine. But let dood go find a job he enjoys for himself as opposed to being forced to endure a grind just to make sure he doesn't die from exposure or starvation. Guy can do whatever he wants

high_score_comments.author: [deleted]
high_score_comments.body: I'M CURRENTLY AT WORK ACROSS THE STREET FROM THAT SCHOOL

high_score_comments.author: ErnaSack
high_score_comments.body: At least pay for his medical bills

high_score_comments.author: SpringhurstAve

high_score_comments.author: fotokopijfo
high_score_comments.body: Dude should never have to work a day in his life - his debt to society is overpaid

high_score_comments.author: [deleted]

high_score_comments.body: The family sued the school, so hopefully they won and were able to use that money to pay for the medical debt

high_score_comments.author: godofwarhigh
high_score_comments.body: They got 90k from the lawsuit :(

high_score_comments.author: cloobydoobydoo
high_score_comments.body: Wtf..

high_score_comments.author: haleyczarrina
high_score_comments.body: What do you mean wtf?? It’s a fucking school! First of all, how was the school even at fault for this?? Second of all, schools are barely making it as is, I’m sure the 90K they paid out just about broke them for the year!

high_score_comments.author: cloobydoobydoo
high_score_comments.body: Family deserves a hell of a lot more is what I mean.

high_score_comments.author: DutytoDevelop
high_score_comments.body: If you risk your life to save others, you shouldn't get a medical bill to begin with. Either the person that injured you should have to pay or the medical bills should be wiped away altogether

high_score_comments.author: Rpanich
high_score_comments.body:
Was it a private school or a state school? 

Because if it’s a state school, his payment should come from the state. 

Security and safety is where the school/ state were at fault: I think we all agree that when a parent drops a child off at school, there is a reasonable degree of safety assumed, and school shootings are a reasonable fear. 

It’s not like getting struck by lighting in Disneyland, it’s like someone pushing people over a small or missing railing into the rollercoaster tracks at Disney.

high_score_comments.author: ch3rriib0mb
high_score_comments.body: This was the Parkland shooting that happened in Florida, so it wasn't private. It's a public school, afaik.

high_score_comments.author: SimplisticPinky
high_score_comments.body: If I remember correctly, when your child is at school, the school is completely responsible for them; I would assume this branches out to not only physical safety, but mental and emotional safety as well. This is why schools have drills, nurses, counsellors, etc. Because the resources the school had to keep this child safe failed, despite his conscious decision, they could easily be sued.

high_score_comments.author: godofwarhigh
high_score_comments.body: The school gets 8 million per year for its budget

high_score_comments.author: haleyczarrina
high_score_comments.body: It is a lot of money to take from a school. I’m shocked they were even able to sue the school, I think the kids a hero and should be compensated but not by taking money from the school!

high_score_comments.author: [deleted]
high_score_comments.body: How does this work. How is it the schools fault?

high_score_comments.author: dancer_jasmine1
high_score_comments.body: I believe the schools are legally liable for the children’s safety while they are at school. I’m pretty sure this is the same reason why parents have to sign permission slips for things like field trips where there’s things a child could get hurt on. The permission slips say the school is not liable if the kid does get hurt on that field trip.

high_score_comments.author: vyrelis
high_score_comments.body:
absurd engine languid voiceless sophisticated literate hunt deliver squealing makeshift

 *This post was mass deleted and anonymized with [Redact](https://redact.dev/home)*

high_score_comments.author: H4irBear
high_score_comments.body:
This kind of shit always takes me aback. Coming from a country where healthcare is free at the point of use, it saddens me to see people have to sue to be in some way taken care of. 

This guy should have been cared for for free and given some state honour or medal for services to his fellow humans. But then again, he should also have had the right to live in a society where poor mental healthcare and ready availability of firearms are not a thing.

high_score_comments.author: [deleted]
high_score_comments.body:
I guarantee his bills were paid for. Even though the private health care system doesn’t care about his heroism, his community definitely paid their debt to him.

Edit: https://www.gofundme.com/f/anthonyborges

$932k was crowdfunded for his bills

high_score_comments.author: cocoabeach

high_score_comments.author: cocoabeach

I was responding to the crowdfunding comment above.  In a first world country he would not have had to beg for money.

Well, someone's gotta stop being a disgrace. Why not the US?

It's not going to be fast, and we're about as much of a disgrace as we've ever been, but we gotta start at some point.

high_score_comments.body:
Yeah... you can't really "two side" the US healthcare system. 

Most civilized countries simply cover their citizen's medical bills. "The entire world is a disgrace" doesn't really cut it.

high_score_comments.author: PhucktheSaints
high_score_comments.body:
Before jumping to the defense of the cop, you might want to look at the details of what the officer who was at the school did that day once the shooting started. 

He has since retired and is currently facing several charges of negligence and perjury.

high_score_comments.body:
Cop was fired but after mediation got his job back. Sheriff resigned.

https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.usatoday.com/amp/5194831002

https://apnews.com/article/047ffcaba91746bcb8b6d7ead5a018f4

high_score_comments.body:
I don’t know how it all panned out but here’s a link to a local paper. And the Wikipedia page about the shooting gives some details too. 

https://www.sun-sentinel.com/local/broward/parkland/florida-school-shooting/fl-ne-peterson-arrest-fair-scapegoat-20190607-umq62ojnorc6llfotayp522dsy-story.html?_gl=1*1x39smw*_ga*Q3Q5N1l4UEhhdC0wcW41cURVZGpRQ2hveWwzaDlrX19QTkZTVFpLOXQtb1R2bWFtSTdnZTNnMkprd2o1SnhLbQ..

He was armed and the first on the scene. But never attempted to confront the shooter. Meanwhile; the schools Athletic Director (unarmed, obviously) was murdered trying to stop the shooter and save those kids. The officer completely failed in his duty to protect that day.

You stubbornly refusing to listen to anything without seeing a video was not valorous, it was stupidity. high_score_comments.author: juttep1
high_score_comments.body: So definitely not a complete recovery. Damn

high_score_comments.author: [deleted]
high_score_comments.body: Yea, there is really no such thing as much as we would all love to think it. When they have to put pins and rods in your body it’s an effective but albeit archaic way to put things back together.

high_score_comments.author: juttep1
high_score_comments.body: Not to mention the trauma...

high_score_comments.author: CurseofLono88
high_score_comments.body: Thank you

high_score_comments.author: FresnoBob-9000
high_score_comments.body: Those scars... fucking hell man. That kids a fucking hero.

high_score_comments.author: bottlecap1231s7
high_score_comments.body: If only there was something we as a country could've done to prevent such a shooting from happening.

high_score_comments.author: WomanNotAGirl
high_score_comments.body: Yep. We are getting in the habit of romanticizing the shit children have to do to create emotion instead of creating a safe environment. He is not a hero. He is a broken child that’s going to suffer from PTSD the rest of his life. After the hype dies down everybody will forget about him except somebody posts this same photo, yet he will get no support the rest of his life. We need to do better. We need to charge these fuckers with terrorism charges, lock them up for life instead of making excuse for them cause they are white. We need to pass the gun laws but before that giving them real consequences will make the next I want to get famous idiot think twice. Society works based on actions and consequences. Instead we are creating an environment where it’s a common thing and herofying a child who had to endure trauma beyond repair. Argh poor baby.

high_score_comments.author: [deleted]
high_score_comments.body:
I understand the point you're trying to make but this kid IS a hero. The circumstances that forced him to act in a heroic fashion are tragic and sadly fixable, but he is still a hero.

I think you're using the term "romanticize" in an incorrect way. To "romanticize" his sacrifice would be to imply that our perception of his heroism is greater than the facts of the situation. Our shortcomings as a society should not take away from the bravery and selflessness of this young man.

high_score_comments.author: [deleted]
high_score_comments.body:
We as a society do not "romanticize" cancer recovery. No one says "oh wouldn't it be so nice to get cancer and recover from it". That's romanticizing something.

"Romanticizing" something is like making a show about a drug dealer who is super successful and never faces any problems, even though selling drugs and living that lifestyle is generally considered a bad thing. 

Romanticizing something, by definition, is taking a bad thing and making it seem good, or romantic. 

This kid is a hero. The circumstances around his heroics don't take away from that.

high_score_comments.author: tinyanus
high_score_comments.body:
Not op, but there are a lot of things we can do besides banning guns.

Working as a community to remove toxic masculinity is one I personally think would help a lot.

Another would be gun *restrictions*, such as not allowing people to buy AR-15s on the internet.

/r/liberalgunowners is a good resource in case you're interested in learning more.

high_score_comments.author: Murka-Lurka
high_score_comments.body:
I live in the U.K. and while we have very strict gun control there isn’t a ban on all guns.

If you want to own a gun you have to prove you know what you are doing, show a legitimate need or interest (be a member of a shooting range/ gun club) and be registered as a gun owner.

If you display any behaviour that means you are unsafe to own a gun, whether it is mental health based or criminal, your guns are confiscated but can be returned if the situation changes.

Nobody questions a driving test or having your license suspended if you are an unsafe driver. Insurance to cover innocent people in the event of an accident. So all it takes is a change in mindset that gun control doesn’t mean a complete ban.

high_score_comments.author: [deleted]
high_score_comments.body: People don't realise that you can legally own a .223 M4 variant in this country, so basically a low powered version of the same round that the British Army use that can actually be fired from the British Army rifle, yet people still think guns are pretty much flat out banned over here.

high_score_comments.author: hoardac
high_score_comments.body: It says well regulated militia. Not against guns just saying it should be regulated better.

Oh that’s for sure. I was in a bad car accident in college and the just the initial hospital stay cost me $20,000, the 2 surgeries were about another $30,000- and that was WITH my insurance.

high_score_comments.author: parkourandinternet
high_score_comments.body: Holy shit, look I am european and in no means am I trying to brag, but tf is wrong with health care in America?! 50k for 2 surgeries and stay is STUPID. I broke my Arm pretty badly twice and we didn't get financially robbed at all. Health care shouldn't be this expensive, it is a human need. I always heard about American Healthcare but holy shit I did not expect that.

high_score_comments.author: Pzykimon
high_score_comments.body: Imagine living somewhere, where you have to fear for your kids life when sending them to school. The guy is a hero, no doubt about it, but [INSERT GENERIC DEVINE ENTITY] fuck on rollerskates, no kids should ever have to do that, let alone in a school.

high_score_comments.author: CinnamonR0Il
high_score_comments.body: Thank you so much for saying it, people don’t realize that this is not normal !

high_score_comments.author: ZestycloseRepeat3904
high_score_comments.body:
>Anthony Borges

I agree completely... I'm a proponent of the US Constitution and a Veteran that served for 6yrs in the military, but I swear those people who are fighting tooth and nail for the 2nd Amendment right to own any gun have never had kids.  They've never woken up in a cold sweat after dreaming their child was a victim of a school shooting or seen their kid nervous to go to school the day after a shooting (even if we're 500 miles away from it).  I'd gladly give up the 2nd amendment to keep my kids and family safe.  Let's be 100% honest too.  If our government ever turned on us, a bunch of hillbillies with AR's won't be enough to save us anyway, so their "Keep the government in check" theory is easily negated. The government has tanks, helicopters, planes, and nukes.  The proud boys wouldn't last a day in a war with the US Government. They couldn't even find a single US Senator on 1/6.

high_score_comments.author: Pzykimon
high_score_comments.body: Very refreshing to read this. Most news we get about the US in Europe these days, are very biased towards showing your countrymed and women as a bunch of ill witted morons. Keep raising the standard and fighting the good fight. Hats off to you sir/mam.

high_score_comments.author: musicwithmxs

I’m a teacher and this pisses me off. There is absolutely no reason for this. The idea that this could be me or any one of my students is infuriating. 

There’s so much to address to fix this, but we could start with some sensible gun reform and actually addressing what makes (mostly white men, look at the damn stats before you @ me) do this in the first place.

He’s no doubt a hero. He just shouldn’t have had to be one.

title: Anthony Borges was 15 yrs old when he was shot 5 times in a school shooting, Feb 14 2018. He barricaded a classroom door and used his body as a shield to save a class full of students from harm.
author: Fluid-Daydreamer

high_score_comments.author: IronSte
high_score_comments.body: School shooting? No prizes for guessing where in the world this happened.

high_score_comments.author: justsomeguyfromny
high_score_comments.body: You gatekeeping saving lives? Lol

high_score_comments.author: lost_last_account_
high_score_comments.body: Idk what bullets he used but it was an AR-15 and considering it’s the deadliest highschool shooting in US history I would say he was pretty prepared and what this kid did was very heroic
